Headline: A Texas manufacturing C.E.O. urges employees to vote Republican.
Lead Paragraph: With Election Day imminent, a prominent Texas business leader last week appeared to urge her employees to consider voting for Donald J. Trump and other Republican candidates.

Headline: In a Hot Election, the Cool-Headed Associated Press Takes Center Stage
Lead Paragraph: The Associated Press will not predict a winner of the presidential election. It will not even name an apparent or likely winner. The A.P. will make the call only when it is certain — just as it has in every U.S. election since 1848, when Zachary Taylor won the White House.

Headline: Vatican Clarifies Pope Francis’s Comments on Same-Sex Unions
Lead Paragraph: ROME — The Vatican has confirmed the pope’s remarks on gay couples deserving civil protections as it sent an explanatory note to bishops underlining that Francis’s comments did not mark a change in church doctrine.

Headline: On Afghan Highways, Even the Police Fear the Taliban’s Toll Collectors
Lead Paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the long-haul trucker drives past this hilltop police outpost in southern Afghanistan each week, he knows exactly what to do. The officers toss down a box tied to a length of rope and like all drivers, the trucker places 5,000 afghanis — about $65 — in the box, which the officers then reel back up to their outpost.

Headline: North Carolina expects few votes to remain uncounted on election night.
Lead Paragraph: President Donald J. Trump returned again to the battleground state of North Carolina on Monday morning, addressing a crowd that had almost entirely voted for him already, in a state that has had heavy early turnout.

Headline: In San Francisco, the virus is contained but schools are still closed.
Lead Paragraph: As a third wave of infections has begun to take off across much of the United States, San Francisco has been a bright spot. The city has tamped down infections to near their lowest levels since the pandemic began. Restaurants, movie theaters, and museums are open at 25 percent of capacity.

Headline: Prince William had Covid-19 in April but kept it a secret.
Lead Paragraph: Prince William contracted Covid-19 in England in April but kept his diagnosis a secret, the BBC and The Sun, England’s largest paper, have reported, citing information from sources within Kensington Palace. A person close to the palace confirmed the accuracy of the reports, but did not offer additional details.

Headline: 99.7 million Americans have already voted, nearly three-quarters of 2016’s total.
Lead Paragraph: Whatever the outcome, the 2020 election is already one for the history books, with an astonishing 99.7 million ballots already submitted through in-person early voting and by mail — nearly three-quarters of the number of votes cast in the entire 2016 election.

Headline: As Boris Johnson Plays Scrooge, Britons Feed the Hungry Themselves
Graham and Harrison Battle Over the ‘New South,’ in Their Final Appeals
As Election Day Arrives, Trump Shifts Between Combativeness and Grievance
Lead Paragraph: President Trump arrives at Election Day on Tuesday toggling between confidence and exasperation, bravado and grievance, and marinating in frustration that he is trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr., whom he considers an unworthy opponent.

Headline: In an Arizona border city, no Biden but long memories on Trump.
Lead Paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — When the campaign bus for Joseph R. Biden Jr. rolled into Nogales, Ariz., about a mile from the U.S. border with Mexico, Tony Estrada, the longtime Democratic sheriff here, was waiting.

Headline: Pelosi: If Trump won’t concede, ‘why would I care?’
Lead Paragraph: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Monday dismissed concerns that President Trump might decline to concede defeat in the election, even if he has clearly lost, calling Mr. Trump’s personal conduct irrelevant to the legal transfer of power in January.

Headline: Whale Sculpture Stops Train From Plunge in the Netherlands
Lead Paragraph: A train that went careening over the end of elevated tracks in the Netherlands on Monday was left teetering about 30 feet above the ground. But no one was injured or killed in the accident — thanks to a sculpture of a whale’s tail that stopped the train from plunging.

Headline: Trump says he will declare victory ‘when there is victory, if there is victory.’
Lead Paragraph: As Election Day dawned, President Trump said Tuesday morning in an interview on “Fox & Friends” that he would declare victory “when there is victory, if there is victory.”

Headline: How to Keep Climbing the Ladder While You Work From Home
Lead Paragraph: You’re stuck working from home, but does your career need to be stuck, too? Worried about keeping employees safe, many companies are pushing return-to-office dates deep into next year, so workers face more months toiling from spare bedrooms and kitchen tables.

Headline: ‘It’s Just Crazy’ in Pennsylvania: Mail Voting and the Anxiety That Followed
Lead Paragraph: KITTANNING, Pa. — “Hello, Elections.”

Headline: Her absentee ballot missing, a Kentucky college student plans to drive 1,052 miles to vote.
Lead Paragraph: Fiona Walsh, a senior at George Washington University, has spent the last month trying to locate her absentee ballot, which never arrived. So she’s going the extra mile.

Headline: Washington, a city on edge about the election, boards itself up.

Headline: The 2020 election’s unnerving end: vandalism, acts of intimidation and riot prep.
Lead Paragraph: Presidential elections always provoke anxiety, but this year’s campaign is closing on an especially unnerving note, with reports of pre-election vandalism, the boarding-up of stores in anticipation of rioting and the specter of voter intimidation.

Headline: To prove his Trump credentials, Doug Collins, Georgia Senate candidate, campaigns with Roger Stone.
Lead Paragraph: BUFORD, Ga. — Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia has spent many weeks, and many of her own millions of dollars, trying to prove she is a more conservative candidate than her bitter rival, Representative Doug Collins, a fellow Republican. In fact, it almost seemed that Ms. Loeffler ran out of room to run rightward when, last month, she welcomed the endorsement of Georgia’s best-known proponent of the QAnon conspiracy theory, Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican congressional candidate.

Headline: A record early vote, and last-minute lawsuits, mark the end of a campaign transformed by the pandemic.
Lead Paragraph: If the final sprint to Election Day appeared superficially familiar, with President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. making their closing arguments to swing state voters, there were plenty of reminders Monday that the 2020 campaign has been anything but normal.

Headline: Battleground States See the Most Voting Misinformation
Lead Paragraph: Which states have seen the highest volume of viral misinformation about voting by mail this election season? Those that are most in play between President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr., according to new data.

Headline: N.Y.C. parents must decide — in two weeks — whether to send children to school.
Lead Paragraph: Over the next two weeks, more than one million parents in New York City must make a wrenching decision: Should they send their children into classrooms this school year or keep them learning from home, likely until at least next fall?

Headline: After the battle for the White House ends, both parties will still face big questions.
Lead Paragraph: Fighting for his political survival from the second floor of his campaign bus last week, Senator John Cornyn warned a small crowd of supporters that his party’s long-held dominance in this historically ruby-red state was at risk.

Headline: The Times has been tracking delays in mail delivery. Last week was one of the slowest to date.
Lead Paragraph: The U.S. Postal Service experienced some of its worst delays all year in the final week before the election, according to a Times project tracking first-class. An avalanche of late-arriving political pamphlets and advertisements appears to have added to backlogs for the Postal Service, after months of slowdowns.

Headline: An English soccer star extends his efforts to feed children in need, as the government does nothing.
Lead Paragraph: The English soccer star Marcus Rashford launched a campaign earlier this year to provide free meals to children who need them, an effort that emerged after widespread disapproval of the way Prime Minister Boris Johnson was handling the impact of the pandemic.

Headline: Florida, Man
Lead Paragraph: Hi, and welcome to this last pre-Election Day installment of On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

Headline: Trump Backers Block Highways as Election Tensions Play Out in the Streets
Lead Paragraph: Vehicles with Trump flags halted traffic on Sunday on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey and jammed the Mario M. Cuomo Bridge between Tarrytown and Nyack, N.Y. Another pro-Trump convoy in Virginia ended in a tense shouting match with protesters as it approached a statue of Robert E. Lee in Richmond.

Headline: U.K.’s Johnson Faces a Growing Revolt Over His Coronavirus Policy
Mount Everest empties as Covid-19 strikes tourism in Nepal.
Lead Paragraph: Last year, Nepal attracted so many mountain climbers that a traffic jam of hundreds of mountaineers snarled a trail to the top of Mount Everest.

Headline: At late-night rally, Trump suggests he may fire Fauci ‘after the election.’
Lead Paragraph: President Trump suggested at a rally early Monday morning that he might fire Dr. Anthony S. Fauci after Election Day, further escalating the tension between his administration and the nation’s top infectious disease expert as the number of new coronavirus cases in the United States reaches record highs.

Headline: Restaurants, wrecked by the pandemic, try creative ways to stay open.
Lead Paragraph: The pandemic has spared almost no business in New York City. Some have thrived, like liquor stores. But no industry has been clobbered like restaurants and bars, a multibillion-dollar lifeblood that gives the city vibrancy and diversity, employs hundreds of thousands of people, including many immigrants, and attracts millions of tourists every year.

Headline: There have been scattered reports of paramilitary groups trying to interfere with voting.
Lead Paragraph: Scattered incidents of illegal paramilitary groups interfering with voting have popped up around the country ahead of Tuesday’s election, according to a Georgetown University Law Center institute that is tracking such episodes.

Headline: Terrorist Shooting in Capital of Austria
Lead Paragraph: A terrorist attack in central Vienna on Monday night left at least four people dead and many others wounded, including a police officer, government officials said.

Headline: Edward Snowden, Expecting a Child, Will Seek Russian Citizenship
Lead Paragraph: MOSCOW — Edward J. Snowden has said that he never quite feels at home in Moscow. He looks away from traffic while crossing the street to avoid the cameras that Russian drivers often affix to their windshields, he wrote in a memoir published last year. And when going outside, he noted, he changes his appearance, down to the rhythm and pace of his walk.

Headline: A Stable Race’s Volatile Finish
Lead Paragraph: As Trump covers the battleground waterfront and Biden tries to avoid another Pennsylvania surprise, the highways have started to feel like the high seas. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

Lead Paragraph: A federal judge in Houston on Monday rejected Republican efforts to invalidate more than 127,000 votes that were cast at drive-through locations in Harris County, a Democratic stronghold that includes Houston, the nation’s fourth-largest city.

Lead Paragraph: BANGKOK — There are certain constants in Thailand: the drenching monsoons, the grand openings of new shopping malls and the rumors that the Royal Thai Armed Forces are plotting another coup.

Headline: Gunmen Storm Kabul University, Killing at Least 19
Lead Paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three gunmen laid siege to Afghanistan’s largest university on Monday, taking hostages, killing at least 19 people and wounding more than a dozen, officials said. It was the second deadly assault with mass casualties on an education center in the capital in just over a week.

Headline: Wisconsin Faces a Challenge: Getting Out the Vote When Most People Have Already Voted
Lead Paragraph: MILWAUKEE — As Wisconsin weathers the worst coronavirus outbreak of any presidential battleground, the state Democratic Party is calling and texting voters instead of going door to door. The Biden campaign’s get-out-the-vote effort in the state is all virtual.

Headline: Trump amps up uncertainty and plays down the pandemic as a chaotic campaign races to its conclusion.
Lead Paragraph: President Trump, adopting a double-barreled closing strategy of maximizing uncertainty over the election and minimizing the pandemic, is vowing to mount a legal challenge to Pennsylvania’s vote count while threatening to fire Dr. Anthony Fauci, the person Americans trust most to tell the truth on the coronavirus.

Headline: Despite a surge in absentee ballots, fewer than expected are being rejected, election officials say.
Lead Paragraph: With absentee ballots flooding election offices nationwide, the officials processing them are tentatively reporting some surprising news: The share of ballots being rejected because of flawed signatures and other errors appears lower — sometimes much lower — than in the past.

Headline: How Long Is This Going to Take? Americans Settle In to Wait
Lead Paragraph: They warned us. They said it would not be over right away. They said it could take days for all the votes to be counted. They told us to wait for the slow gears of democracy to grind toward a conclusion.

Headline: What the Last Pre-Election Polls Reveal About Where Things Stand
Lead Paragraph: A flood of heavily Democratic ballots has already streamed into election offices around the country during the weeks of early voting. Headline: A coronavirus study in Germany offers hope for concertgoers.
Lead Paragraph: Researchers in Germany may have some good news for frustrated concertgoers around the world whose activities have been constrained by the spread of the coronavirus.

Headline: Photos From Election Day 2020
Lead Paragraph: A year that began with the incumbent facing impeachment and the opponent facing a tumultuous primary has come down to this. The race between President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. will come to an end on Tuesday as voters head to the polls across the country. Those casting ballots today join the more than 100 million who did so in the preceding weeks.

Headline: How will turnout compare to last time? Four states already have more votes than they did in 2016.
Lead Paragraph: In Hawaii, which is running an all-mail vote for the first time, 484,000 voters had already cast their ballots, compared to 429,000 in 2016. In Texas, almost as many people voted early in person — 8.7 million — as voted in total in the last presidential election.

Headline: Ivory Coast President Wins Third Term in Disputed Vote
Lead Paragraph: Electoral officials said Tuesday that President Alassane Ouattara of Ivory Coast had won a third term in a landslide. But his two main opponents boycotted the election and refused to recognize the results, raising fears that the West African nation could spiral deeper into political violence.

Headline: Michigan officials warn of robocalls meant to mislead residents in Flint.
Lead Paragraph: Michigan officials warned voters of robocalls on Tuesday morning, saying that calls were going to residents in Flint, a city with a large Black population, in an effort to confuse voters and lower turnout.

Headline: ‘I feel very good,’ President Trump tells campaign workers during an Election Day visit to a Republican office.
Lead Paragraph: President Trump paid a call to a Republican office in Virginia on Tuesday and, despite trailing in the polls, predicted “a great night” and basked in the memories of the rallies he staged in his bid for a second term.

Headline: At a refugee camp at the U.S.-Mexico border, prospective migrants hope for a Biden win.
Lead Paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — Enda Marisol Rivera and Vilma Consuelo Vasquez sat at a rickety wooden table under tattered tarps, peeling the bananas they were eating for breakfast and talking about the nerves they had woken up with this morning.

Headline: Hundreds Die at Sea Off Senegal’s Coast on a Perilous Route to Europe
Lead Paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — An estimated 150 migrants are thought to have died after the wooden boat they were traveling in was shipwrecked off the coast of Senegal on Friday, the latest in a deadly series of accidents for those trying a dangerous sea route around northwest Africa to reach Europe that had become less popular in recent years.

Headline: With election and jobs report as a backdrop, the Fed will get its turn this week.

Biden Jr.’s middling gains with white Floridians.

Headline: Fulton County, which includes most of Atlanta, is expected to finish counting its ballots overnight.

Headline: Polls have begun to close in much of Florida.

Headline: Democrats’ path to Senate control narrows as Republicans hold onto critical seats.
Lead Paragraph: Democrats’ path to seizing the Senate continued to narrow Wednesday as Republicans held onto a cluster of seats in critical states and the two parties continued to fight to control the upper chamber of Congress in close contests across the country.

Headline: Democrats’ hopes of a blowout in New York fade as incumbents and candidates fall to Republicans.
Lead Paragraph: Democrats in New York who had hoped to capitalize on anti-Trump sentiment and pick up several congressional seats across the state were delivered sobering news this week, with two first-term Democratic congressmen in danger of losing and candidates far behind in three other districts the party had hoped to flip.

Headline: Having Made Peace Abroad, Ethiopia’s Leader Goes to War at Home

Headline: The Trump Presidency Is Ending. So Is Maggie Haberman’s Wild Ride.

On election night, as the votes started coming in, she was seated at her dining room table with her husband and one of her three children, drinking from a liter bottle of Foodtown raspberry seltzer, eating leftover Kit Kats from Halloween, typing and texting, and, still, still, working her sources.

He later served as Mr. Biden’s chief of staff when he was vice president, helping oversee the 2009 economic rescue package, and later acting as President Barack Obama’s “Ebola czar.”

Headline: Disney+ Passes 73 Million Subscribers as Streaming Takes Center Stage

Headline: Republican distrust of news may be helping election misinformation spread.
Lead Paragraph: In looking for reasons behind the misinformation that is casting doubt about last week’s election Joseph R. Biden Jr., some researchers are drawing a link to the growing distrust of the news media among conservatives.

Headline: Putting the Sport Back in S.U.V.s, 2 Jeep Rivals Sell the Off-Grid Life
Lead Paragraph: One of the more counterintuitive automotive developments of the coronavirus era — with all the stay-at-home orders and work-from-home policies — has been the rejuvenated pull of cars built for taming the great outdoors. Look no further than the (socially distant) commotion that has greeted the recent introductions of two new off-road autos with famous nameplates, the Land Rover Defender and the Ford Bronco.

Headline: How the PlayStation became Sony’s centerpiece product.
Lead Paragraph: As it prepares to start selling its fifth major game console in 25 years on Thursday, Sony has largely become the PlayStation company, reports Seth Schiesel.

Headline: Corey Lewandowski, a Trump campaign adviser, has tested positive for the virus.
Lead Paragraph: Corey Lewandowski, a Trump campaign adviser who has been working on efforts to bring lawsuits contesting the election outcome in several states, tested positive for the coronavirus on Wednesday, a person briefed on the diagnosis said Thursday.

Headline: How the Dream of Hong Kong Democracy Was Dimmed
Lead Paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s pro-democracy lawmakers said Wednesday they would resign en masse to protest Beijing’s growing control over the local legislature, one of the last remaining centers of dissent in the Chinese city.

Headline: A Police Swarm. Frantic Calls. Then 3,000 People Locked Inside.

It was, witnesses said, like a scene from an action movie — but instead of responding to a terrorist threat, the officers were responding to a coronavirus spike.

Headline: Turkmenistan’s President Gives His Favorite Dog a Golden Treat

Headline: British Nurse Is Charged With Murder of Several Babies in Her Care
Lead Paragraph: LONDON — A British nurse has been charged with several counts of murder as part of an investigation into infant deaths at the neonatal unit of a hospital in northwestern England, the police said in a statement on Wednesday, in a case that has haunted the community for years.

Headline: Down to one job, she worries about money and a child’s health.

Headline: No Unlawful Pay Discrimination at the BBC? A Finding Is Quickly Disputed

Headline: One America News spreads debunked elections claims.

Headline: Syria Seeks Return of Refugees, but They Fear Leader’s Wrath

Headline: New Unemployment Claims Dip, but Economic Pain Persists
Lead Paragraph: New claims for benefits continued to flood state unemployment offices last week as the coronavirus pandemic inflicted further economic damage.

Headline: Britain’s economy grew by a record, but a contraction looms.

Headline: Biden Plans as Trump Holds Out

Headline: ‘A Black Eye’: Why Political Polling Missed the Mark. Again.

Headline: Democrats demand a big stimulus plan as Republicans insist on targeted relief.

When someone asked him where he lived in Melbourne, my son used a large public housing tower at the end of our street as a landmark, saying “I live a block behind those commission flats.” His classmates immediately started teasing him, jeering that he actually lived in public housing.

Lead Paragraph: Volunteering has fallen sharply in the pandemic, creating an enormous financial burden on the nonprofit organizations that have long depended on the free assistance.

Headline: Sainted Too Soon? Vatican Report Cast John Paul II in Harsh New Light

Headline: With Trench Warfare Deepening, Parties Face Unsettled Electoral Map

Headline: They Once Ruled Ethiopia. Now They Are Fighting Its Government.

Headline: Her Abuse Was a ‘Family Matter,’ Until It Went Live

Lead Paragraph: Nanaia Mahuta entered New Zealand’s Parliament as the youngest Maori woman to ever gain a seat. More than two decades later, she has become the country’s minister of foreign affairs, another trailblazing first. So when she was asked at a recent news conference about another woman of color breaking barriers halfway around the world, she broke into a wide smile.

Headline: Trump has amplified voting falsehoods in over 300 tweets since election night.
Lead Paragraph: President Trump has posted over 300 tweets attacking the integrity of the 2020 election since election night, unleashing a cascade of false and misleading claims. Here’s a review.

Headline: Ad giant WPP is folding its Geometry agency into VMLY&R.
Lead Paragraph: WPP, one of the largest advertising companies in the world, is further condensing its sprawling operations by folding its Geometry agency into its VMLY&R agency.

Headline: Spain’s Other Covid Casualties: Undetected Cancer Cases
Lead Paragraph: MADRID — Last March, as the coronavirus was tearing across Spain, Lídia Bayona Gómez started to suffer bouts of vomiting and coughing.

Headline: Joe Biden speaks about the economy as the virus surges and vaccine hopes rise.
Lead Paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the slowing American economic recovery on Monday, amid the crosswinds of rising coronavirus deaths and soaring optimism over a vaccine.

Headline: Division Among the Democrats
Lead Paragraph: For four years, Democrats had been united behind the mission of defeating President Trump.

Headline: As Brazil’s Covid Crisis Eases, Bolsonaro Sees Rising Popularity
Lead Paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro seemed to be on a political suicide mission during the early weeks of the coronavirus crisis in Brazil.

Headline: Australia’s stock exchange shuts down for a day after a software glitch
Lead Paragraph: The Australian Stock Exchange closed early on Monday following a glitch after upgrades went live, in the bourse’s worst outage since 2016.

Headline: Instead of Regaining Momentum, Johnson Is Stalled at Home Again
Lead Paragraph: LONDON — For Prime Minister Boris Johnson, this was supposed to be a critical week to reset his government after a tumultuous round of infighting that led to the abrupt ouster of his most influential adviser, Dominic Cummings.

Headline: Hurricane Iota Makes Landfall in Nicaragua
Lead Paragraph: This live coverage has ended. See our most recent updates on Hurricane Iota here.

Headline: More Republicans call for a smooth transition as Trump continues spreading baseless fraud claims.
Lead Paragraph: Even as more top Republicans urged President Trump on Sunday to allow for an orderly presidential transition, the president himself, after briefly appearing to acknowledge his election loss, resumed spreading the kinds of baseless accusations of election fraud that his supporters have embraced.

Headline: Claims of voter fraud are common. It’s the fraud that’s rare.
Lead Paragraph: In the 1941 Orson Welles epic “Citizen Kane,” newspapermen huddle near the printing press on election night as it becomes clear that the results won’t be good news for their boss, the publishing mogul Charles Foster Kane.

Headline: Trump’s S.E.C. Chairman Is Stepping Down
Lead Paragraph: 🚨 The DealBook Online Summit starts on Tuesday, Nov. 17. Register now to watch for free from anywhere. The newsmakers in the lineup for the first day of the two-day summit are sure to make headlines:

Headline: Fox News’s ‘partisan right’ audience on YouTube is dropping, researchers say.
Lead Paragraph: Disinformation about election fraud is thriving on YouTube, and right-wing outlets that most aggressively push false information are gaining new, conservative viewers on the video service, according to new research.

Headline: A former right-wing media creator on how a ‘different reality’ became so prominent.
Lead Paragraph: Matthew Sheffield started his first conservative website in 2000, dedicating it to criticizing the former CBS News anchor Dan Rather, who Mr. Sheffield believed was a partisan liberal and not critical enough of President Clinton during the Monica Lewinsky scandal. Mr. Sheffield then went on to help create NewsBusters, another right-leaning website that criticized the mainstream media for liberal bias. Later, he became the founding online managing editor of the Washington Examiner, another popular outlet for conservative views.

Headline: Joe Biden’s first economic test: the size and urgency of stimulus efforts.
Lead Paragraph: The incoming administration’s first economic test is coming months before Inauguration Day. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. must decide whether to push Democratic leaders to cut a quick deal on a package much smaller than they say is needed or to hold out hope for a larger one after he takes office, Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley reported in The New York Times.

Headline: Peru Chooses 3rd President in a Week Amid Street Protests
Lead Paragraph: Peru’s legislature on Monday selected the country’s third president in a week, seeking to stanch growing street protests over lawmakers’ decision to remove a popular president from office last week.

Headline: Japanese ‘Monster Wolf’ Aims to Scare Off Wild Bears
Democrats and Republicans face perhaps the most up-for-grabs electoral landscape in a generation.
Lead Paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s two major parties had hoped the 2020 presidential election would render a decisive judgment on the country’s political trajectory. But after a race that broke records for voter turnout and campaign spending, neither Democrats nor Republicans have achieved the upper hand.

Headline: For a preview of President Biden, look to his past.
Lead Paragraph: Like President Bill Clinton, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is an empathetic extrovert with a sprawling network of friends. Like President George W. Bush, he respects American political traditions, and with President Barack Obama, he shares eight years of history, experiences and some Washington battle scars.

Headline: The President vs. the American Media
Lead Paragraph: The president has some bones to pick with the American media: about our “bias,” our obsession with racism, our views on terrorism, our reluctance to express solidarity, even for a moment, with his embattled republic.

Headline: PNC Strikes $11.6 Billion Deal to Buy U.S. Operations of Spanish Bank BBVA
Lead Paragraph: PNC Financial Services said on Monday that it would acquire the U.S. business of the Spanish lender BBVA for $11.6 billion.

Headline: Biden’s adviser picks point to stronger financial regulations.
Lead Paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. last week placed proponents of stronger regulation on financial regulatory teams, stoking fears by industry groups that he is preparing for an unexpected wave of corporate oversight.

Headline: Britain’s prime minister is quarantining, and other news around the world.
Lead Paragraph: Seven months after he battled a serious case of Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain announced on Sunday that he was quarantining after coming into contact with a lawmaker later found to be infected.

Headline: Speaking on the economy, Biden says ‘we can deliver immediate relief’ and calls on Congress to act quickly.
Lead Paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. warned that a “very dark winter” was ahead and called on Congress to pass an economic stimulus package immediately to help workers struggling to cope with the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: Airbnb Reveals Falling Revenue, With Travel Hit by Pandemic
Lead Paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb, the home rental service that disrupted the travel industry and was itself disrupted by the coronavirus, took a major step toward one of the year’s largest initial public offerings when it revealed declining revenue and growing losses in a prospectus on Monday.

Headline: Pro-E.U. Candidate Wins Moldova Election Over Putin-Backed Rival
Lead Paragraph: MOSCOW — Maia Sandu, a Harvard-educated economist who supports closer ties with the European Union, has won a presidential election in Moldova against an incumbent whom President Vladimir V. Putin had openly endorsed.

Headline: Biden and Harris will speak about the economy today.
Lead Paragraph: As the nation faces the twin crises of the coronavirus pandemic and an economy it has ravaged, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris will speak this afternoon about their long-term plans to oversee the recovery.

Headline: Election Security Experts Contradict Trump’s Voting Claims
Lead Paragraph: Fifty-nine of the country’s top computer scientists and election security experts rebuked President Trump’s baseless claims of voter fraud and hacking on Monday, writing that such assertions are “unsubstantiated or are technically incoherent.”

Headline: Japan’s Economy Surges, but the Comeback May Not Last
Lead Paragraph: TOKYO — Japan became the latest major economy to bounce back from the devastation of the coronavirus, as lockdowns eased and pent-up demand led to surging domestic consumption and a rebound in exports.

Headline: Michelle Obama, who helped Melania Trump in 2016, criticizes the Trumps for hindering Biden’s transition.
Lead Paragraph: Michelle Obama suggested President Trump was treating the transition like “a game” on Monday and pleaded with Republicans to “honor the electoral process” by accepting Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect.

Headline: ‘You Could Compare It to a Picasso’: Pigeon Sells for $1.9 Million
Lead Paragraph: In the pigeon racing world, breeding brings big bucks — but never before as much as for New Kim, a 2-year-old female pigeon who sold for a record 1.6 million euros, about $1.9 million, after a bidding war between two Chinese buyers at a Belgian auction.

Headline: Trump Admits Defea … Never Mind
Lead Paragraph: Marchers assembled in the nation’s capital to show their support for the president, but top Republicans are increasingly urging him to accept the election’s result. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

Headline: Hungary and Poland Threaten E.U. Stimulus Over Rule of Law Links
Lead Paragraph: BRUSSELS — When European Union leaders announced a landmark stimulus package to rescue their economies from the ravages of the coronavirus, they agreed to jointly raise hundreds of billions of dollars to use as aid — a bold and widely welcomed leap in collaboration never attempted in the bloc’s history.

Headline: U.K. Diplomat Is Praised in China After Saving Drowning Woman
Lead Paragraph: Teetering on the edge of a slippery rock, a young woman loses her footing and plunges into a river. Moments later, she flails and then floats face-down as one shocked onlooker screams, “Hurry, hurry, save her!”

Headline: Buoyed by Biden’s win, Palestinians say they’ll resume cooperation with Israel.

Headline: Kind bars will be acquired by Mars, the maker of Snickers.
Lead Paragraph: Mars, the company behind M&M’s and Snickers, is acquiring the company that makes Kind bars, the snacks that celebrate their lack of artificial flavors and preservatives, company executives told The New York Times in an interview.

Headline: How Obama Sees This Moment
Lead Paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

Headline: Pfizer says it will work with four states to refine plans for rolling out its vaccine.
Lead Paragraph: The drug maker Pfizer says it will work with four states — Rhode Island, Texas, New Mexico, and Tennessee — to refine their plans for delivering and administering its Covid-19 vaccine before the vaccine receives its expected authorization. The step reflects the complexity of distributing on a large scale a vaccine that requires ultracold storage.

Headline: Tesla is joining the S&P 500, and that could have investors scrambling to buy its shares.
Lead Paragraph: Tesla will join the S&P 500 next month, earning a mark of corporate maturity that may only add to the remarkable rise in its stock price.

Headline: No, Trump did not win in Nevada.
Lead Paragraph: President Trump claimed a “big victory” on Monday night after officials in Clark County, Nev., voted to rerun one local race that had a margin of just 10 votes.

Headline: Biden was asked about canceling student loan debt. Progressives saw an opening.
Lead Paragraph: The question that the reporter asked Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday was simple enough: Did canceling student-loan debt figure into his plans for the economy and would he take executive action to do so?

Headline: Not Dead Yet: News Site Mistakenly Runs Dozens of V.I.P. Obituaries
Lead Paragraph: PARIS — The reports of their deaths really were, as the saying goes, greatly exaggerated.

Headline: Corbyn Reinstated by Labour After He Walks Back Anti-Semitism Remarks

Headline: As Brazil’s virus crisis eases, Jair Bolsonaro’s popularity rises.
Lead Paragraph: President Jair Bolsonaro seemed to be on a political suicide mission during the early weeks of the coronavirus crisis in Brazil.

Lead Paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp is making a play for Simon & Schuster, the venerable home to best-selling authors like Stephen King and Hillary Clinton that raised a ruckus this year after releasing a string of hit titles critical of President Trump.

Biden Jr. and later demanded the hand recount.

Headline: A website funded by right-wing groups gains followers with debunked voting fraud claims.
Lead Paragraph: A prominent electoral map on the website of Everylegalvote.com, a self-described fraud-buster, conveyed an alternate reality on Monday.

Lead Paragraph: BRUSSELS — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has promised to move quickly to rejoin the nuclear deal with Iran so long as Iran also comes back into compliance. But that vow is easier said than done.

Rafael Reif, the president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, delivered an intellectual call to arms to the university’s faculty in November 2017: Help generate insights into how advancing technology has changed and will change the work force, and what policies would create opportunity for more Americans in the digital economy.

Lead Paragraph: While President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has taken steps to demonstrate his distance from lobbyists, his presidency is being welcomed in Washington’s influence industry.

Lead Paragraph: For millions of working women, the coronavirus pandemic has delivered a rare and ruinous one-two-three punch.

Headline: Key takeaways from the hearing, by the numbers.

Lead Paragraph: President Trump’s campaign has until 6 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday to pay $7.9 million if it wants to pursue a recount of the state’s 3.2 million ballots. Lead Paragraph: Don’t be surprised if Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, starts to sound repetitive at Tuesday’s Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on censorship and social media. He has done this before.

Lead Paragraph: Ethan Zhang needed to get back to work. Work was in Ivory Coast, however, and since January the global coronavirus outbreak had stranded the 26-year-old translator in mainland China.

Lead Paragraph: Yeshiva University was in trouble, and Pebb Capital saw an opportunity.

Lead Paragraph: Of all the social media platforms, Twitter has lately been especially aggressive in disputing inaccurate election-related posts and hiding messages. That means Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief executive, may face particular fire while testifying in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday about social media and censorship.

Headline: Biden’s Economic Plan for the Virus
Lead Paragraph: Biden warns of fatal consequences as Trump stonewalls on the transition, and Whitmer faces more blowback over the restrictions in Michigan. It’s Tuesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

Headline: German Police Arrest 3 Suspects in Heist of Royal Jewels
Lead Paragraph: BERLIN — The German police said on Tuesday that they had arrested three men with links to organized crime and were searching for two other suspects in connection with the theft of gold, diamonds and other precious stones from three highly prized collections of Baroque royal jewels in a museum in Dresden last year.

Headline: Here’s what you need to know about today’s hearing.
Lead Paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, and Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief, are appearing before members of the Senate Judiciary Committee to defend actions by their companies to moderate speech. It is the second time in two months that the two C.E.O.s are testifying but this will probably have more fireworks than their last appearance as their companies took a central role during the recent election.

Headline: Here’s the DealBook summit Day 2 lineup.
Lead Paragraph: On Day 2 of the DealBook Online Summit, we will hear from more top leaders from business, policy and culture on the world’s economic challenges, innovation in the age of Big Tech and the role of corporations in addressing racial inequality.

Headline: In China, people scramble for shots of unproven vaccines.
Lead Paragraph: China has made its unproven vaccine candidates widely available to demonstrate their safety and effectiveness to a country that has long been skeptical of vaccines after a spate of quality scandals.

Headline: Democrats call for more regulation of the tech industry.
Lead Paragraph: Democrats showed no signs of letting up on criticisms of Facebook and Twitter at the hearing despite greater efforts by the companies to act on misinformation in the recent election.

Headline: In sign of strain, Huawei will sell its budget smartphone brand, Honor.
Lead Paragraph: The beleaguered Chinese tech giant Huawei said on Tuesday that it would sell its budget smartphone brand, Honor, to a Chinese state-owned entity, in a sign of the strain the company is under as the Trump administration’s restrictions on its business start to bite.

Headline: Trump has considered a strike on Iran before he leaves office.
Lead Paragraph: President Trump has been dissuaded from striking Iran in recent days after his aides warned it could escalate into a broader conflict in his last weeks in office.

Speakers will consider the arc of innovation, the prospects for beating the pandemic, the race for a Covid-19 vaccine, and the future of policymaking in Washington.

Lead Paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.

Headline: Hurricane Iota Poses Threat of Floods and Landslides in Central America
Lead Paragraph: This live coverage has ended.

Headline: No, the Georgia recount does not include reverifying signatures.
Lead Paragraph: As Georgia election officials work to complete a recount of nearly five million ballots by Wednesday, President Trump is trying to cast doubt on the legitimacy of the process — a hand recount that his own campaign demanded.

Headline: Store Accused of Fat Shaming for Calling Large-Size Women’s Clothing ‘Rotten’
Lead Paragraph: HONG KONG — “Slim.” “Beautiful.” “Rotten.” “Extra Rotten.” “Rotten to the Core.”

Headline: How Twitter and Facebook plan to handle Trump’s accounts when he leaves office.
Lead Paragraph: Many world leaders generally have wider latitude on Twitter and Facebook because their comments and posts are regarded as political speech that is in the realm of public interest. But what will happen to President Trump’s accounts on the social media platforms when he leaves office?

Headline: Lawmakers drill down on how Facebook and Twitter moderate content.
Lead Paragraph: At Tuesday’s hearing on social media and misinformation, much of the discussion focused on the minutiae of how Facebook and Twitter carry out the process of moderating the billions of pieces of content regularly posted to their networks.

Lead Paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian Authority said Tuesday that it was resuming its cooperation with Israel, ending six months of financial hardship for tens of thousands of West Bank residents and signaling relief over the election of Joseph R. Biden Jr.

Headline: No, a high-level member of the Biden campaign was not arrested in Texas.
Lead Paragraph: In recent days, conservative websites have reported that a high-level staff member in Texas for the election campaign of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. was arrested on charges of voter fraud for his role in supposedly helping to orchestrate a ballot harvesting scheme.

Headline: Kind Bars to Be Acquired by Maker of Snickers
Lead Paragraph: Mars, the company behind M&M’s and Snickers, is acquiring the maker of Kind bars, the snacks that celebrate their lack of artificial flavors and preservatives, company executives told The New York Times in an interview.

Headline: Lindsey Graham’s Long-Shot Mission to Unravel the Election Results
Lead Paragraph: In 2016, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina praised the integrity of the nation’s elections system, criticizing claims by Donald J. Trump that the vote was “rigged.”

Headline: Republicans Stall in Challenging the Election
Lead Paragraph: What does Rudy Giuliani consider a fair daily rate for pressing unfounded legal claims about the validity of an election? Spoiler alert: It annualizes to about $5 million. Headline: Democrats nominate Nancy Pelosi for another term as speaker, as she suggests it could be her last.
Lead Paragraph: House Democrats, preparing for what may be the slimmest majority in two decades, re-elected Speaker Nancy Pelosi as their leader on Wednesday by voice vote, formally nominating the California Democrat for another term as speaker, which she later suggested could be her last.

Headline: Mexico, Outraged at Arrest of Ex-Official, Threatened to Toss U.S. Agents
Lead Paragraph: From the moment U.S. federal agents arrested a former Mexican defense minister last month on drug trafficking charges, the highest levels of the Mexican government were outraged at being kept in the dark about the case, seeing it as an egregious breach of trust between allies.

Headline: Kevin McCarthy, the House Minority Leader, Doesn’t Think Trump Is Going Away
Lead Paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all the drama around the presidential race, the biggest surprise of the 2020 election may have been in the House, as Republicans gained seats and cut into the Democratic majority after a campaign in which officials in both parties expected the G.O.P. to lose seats.

Headline: Apple Halves Its App Store Fee for the Smaller Companies
Lead Paragraph: Apple, facing growing antitrust scrutiny over what it charges other companies for access to its App Store, said on Wednesday that it would cut in half the fee it took from the smallest app developers.

Headline: Boris Johnson Lays Out U.K. Plan for a ‘Green Industrial Revolution’
Lead Paragraph: LONDON — Five years after deciding to phase out the use of coal, Britain took steps on Wednesday to address some of the country’s largest remaining sources of greenhouse gas emissions, announcing plans to end the sale of new gas and diesel cars within a decade and change the way people heat their homes.

Headline: The pandemic makes young people more open to radicalization, British police say.
Lead Paragraph: British police say the coronavirus pandemic and the subsequent social isolation have contributed to a “perfect storm” that is making more young people vulnerable to radicalization.

Headline: LeBron James Joins the Line-up for Day 2 of the DealBook Online Summit
Lead Paragraph: It’s the last day of our Online Summit, and we are announcing a special final panel: At 4 p.m. Eastern, watch the N.B.A. star LeBron James and Sherrilyn Ifill of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund speak with Andrew about the election and the More than a Vote campaign, which Mr. James founded to help make voting more accessible. More details about this and today’s other sessions below.

Headline: Northern Ireland Man Arrested Decades After Infamous Birmingham Bombings
Lead Paragraph: LONDON — The police have arrested a man in Northern Ireland in connection with the notorious bombing of two pubs in the English Midlands almost a half-century ago, they said Wednesday, an attack whose memory has endured as an emblem of deferred justice and enduring loss.

Headline: Many Republican governors still won’t state plainly that Biden won.
Lead Paragraph: Ten days after the presidential race was called for Joseph R. Biden Jr., only about a half-dozen of the nation’s 26 Republican governors have unequivocally acknowledged his victory or said that President Trump should concede.

Headline: Dolly Parton donated $1 million to help develop a coronavirus vaccine.
Lead Paragraph: She wrote “I Will Always Love You” and “Jolene” on the same day and built a theme park around herself. She has given memorable onscreen performances as a wisecracking hairstylist and a harassed secretary. She even helped bring about the creation of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.”

Headline: ‘Within Seconds Everything Was Gone’: Devastating Floods Submerge the Philippines
Lead Paragraph: TUGUEGARAO CITY, Philippines — Brown water submerged nearly everything, as entire villages were swallowed by the deluge.

Headline: Trump fires a cybersecurity official who called the election ‘the most secure in American history.’
Lead Paragraph: President Trump on Tuesday night fired his administration’s most senior cybersecurity official responsible for securing the presidential election, Christopher Krebs, who had systematically disputed Mr. Trump’s false declarations that the presidency was stolen from him through fraudulent ballots and software glitches that changed millions of votes.

Headline: Asylum Seeker Who Lost His Son on Trek to Greece Is Charged in His Death
Lead Paragraph: ATHENS — Greek authorities have charged an Afghan man in the death of his 6-year-old son as the pair tried to reach the country by sea, a move that rights groups say sets a worrying precedent in criminalizing migrants and is part of a strategy to dissuade them from attempting to travel to the country.

Headline: Boeing 737 Max Is Cleared by F.A.A. to Fly Again
Lead Paragraph: After 20 months on the ground, Boeing’s 737 Max will soon fly again, ending a tragic episode that cost 346 people their lives and did serious damage to the big U.S. jet builder.

Headline: How the Out-of-Control Pandemic Is Speeding the Testing of Vaccines
Lead Paragraph: The coronavirus is spreading out of control in the United States, overwhelming health systems and killing more than 1,100 Americans a day. But there is a slender silver lining: It is hastening the testing of vaccines that could eventually end the pandemic.

Headline: Kentucky closes its schools and bans indoor dining again as virus cases surge.
Lead Paragraph: Kentucky will suspend all in-person instruction in elementary, middle and high schools beginning next week, ban indoor service at bars and restaurants and impose new limits on indoor gatherings, Gov. Andy Beshear announced on Wednesday, citing a steep rise in coronavirus cases and hospitalizations in the state.“We are in the midst of exponential growth,” Governor Beshear said. “Our top five highest days ever in this virus of positive cases have all been in the last week.”

Headline: Turkey, accused of understating the crisis, cancels in-person classes.
Lead Paragraph: The Turkish government, facing growing public anger over its handling of the pandemic and accusations that it is hiding the true toll of the coronavirus, announced that it would close classrooms and impose new restrictions on movement on weekends as part of a raft of measures as the death toll in the country steadily rises.

Headline: Election misinformation often evaded YouTube’s efforts to stop it.
Lead Paragraph: YouTube videos endorsing the false idea that there was widespread election fraud were viewed more than 138 million times on the week of Nov. 3, according to a report from an independent research project that has been studying misinformation trends on the video site.

Headline: Catch up on the latest news, from the DealBook newsletter.
Lead Paragraph: Every day, the DealBook newsletter helps subscribers makes sense of the latest business and policy news. Here are some of the stories in today’s edition:

Headline: G.O.P. faces outcry in Michigan after refusing to certify vote: ‘You could see the racism.’
Lead Paragraph: DETROIT — Mayor Mike Duggan of Detroit on Wednesday accused President Trump’s allies in Michigan’s most populous county of racism after they initially refused to certify the election results over slight discrepancies in majority-Black precincts — while ignoring similar problems in heavily white areas.

Headline: Linda Henry, Who Owns Boston Globe With Her Husband, Becomes Its C.E.O.
Lead Paragraph: Linda Pizzuti Henry on Wednesday became the chief executive officer of Boston Globe Media Partners, the parent company of The Boston Globe, Boston.com and STAT News. Along with her husband, John W. Henry, Ms. Henry is an owner of Boston Globe Media Partners, the Boston Red Sox and the Liverpool Football Club.

Headline: Watch: Day 2 at the DealBook summit.
An out-of-control pandemic is speeding the hunt for vaccines.
Lead Paragraph: In the past week, the United States has reported a daily average of nearly 160,000 new coronavirus cases. The virus is overwhelming health systems and killing more than 1,100 Americans a day. But there is a slender silver lining: It is hastening the testing of vaccines that could eventually end the pandemic.

Headline: Abandoning its loose approach to virus controls, Sweden clamps down.
Lead Paragraph: In the spring, as European governments imposed draconian lockdown orders that turned capitals into ghost towns and forced people to largely confine themselves to their homes, Sweden opted for a lighter touch.

Headline: How to Have a Fully Remote Family Thanksgiving
Lead Paragraph: Because of the relentless pandemic, many people are staying home for Thanksgiving this year. No technology can ever fully replace an in-person holiday gathering. But it is possible to recreate some family traditions online or even learn new skills — like roasting turkey.

Headline: ‘Jetman’ Who Flew Beside a Plane Dies While Training in Dubai
Lead Paragraph: Vincent Reffet, a French stuntman known for limit-defying jumps from the world’s tallest towers and highest mountains, and aerial feats alongside planes using a jetpack, died in Dubai during a training session on Tuesday, his company said. He was 36.

Headline: Giuliani peddles election conspiracy theories and falsehoods.
Lead Paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, has spread a litany of falsehoods and conspiracy theories in media appearances and social media over the past week.

Headline: The vaccines will probably work. Making them fast will be the hard part.
Lead Paragraph: The promising news that not just one but two coronavirus vaccines were more than 90 percent effective in early results has buoyed hopes that an end to the pandemic is in sight.

Headline: Children in the U.S. may miss 9 million vaccine doses this year, a report warns.
Lead Paragraph: Children in the United States are on pace this year to miss nine million vaccine doses for measles, polio and other highly contagious diseases, according to medical claims data — a disruption that health care authorities called alarming and attributed to the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: When Michigan Republicans Refused to Certify Votes, It Wasn’t Normal
Lead Paragraph: For a few hours on Tuesday, it looked as though two Republican officials in Wayne County, Mich., might reject the will of hundreds of thousands of voters.

Headline: Boeing’s 737 Max Will Be Flying Again. What Do Travelers Need to Know?
Lead Paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration has lifted its ban on Boeing’s 737 Max, allowing the plane to return to the skies after being grounded for more than 20 months following crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia that killed 346 people.

Headline: Something Elizabeth Warren and Jamie Dimon agree on: The presidential transition must begin.
Lead Paragraph: The consequences of President Trump’s refusal to concede the election has leaders in government and business worried. Speaking at the DealBook Online Summit Tuesday and Wednesday, they said administrative delays threaten a smooth transition that’s especially critical in a pandemic and amid economic crisis. Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren said she was “very worried about the transition process.”

Headline: Second Epstein Investigation Begins at Victoria’s Secret, but What’s Changed?
Lead Paragraph: It has been more than a year since L Brands, the owner of Victoria’s Secret, said it was hiring a law firm to investigate its billionaire founder Leslie H. Wexner’s close ties to the convicted sex criminal Jeffrey Epstein, but no findings have been made public and the review has seemed to fade from view.

Headline: Layers of Tragedy, in a Cemetery and in the Mountains
Lead Paragraph: KELBAJAR, Azerbaijan — It’s the little things that stick with you.

Headline: Iran accelerates its nuclear program while offering Biden a path back from confrontation.
Lead Paragraph: Days after President Trump asked for options to take military action against Iran’s major nuclear site, the government in Tehran has sent conflicting signals, taking a major step to speed up its production of nuclear fuel but also offering President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. a way to defuse a potential confrontation.

Headline: New Orleans cancels 2021 Mardi Gras parades, which normally draw seas of tourists.
Lead Paragraph: New Orleans announced that there would be no parades during the February 2021 Mardi Gras celebrations, bowing to the near-certainty that the coronavirus pandemic will remain a public health crisis through the winter.

Headline: Pompeo and Bahraini Minister Visit Israel After Strikes on Iranian Forces in Syria
Lead Paragraph: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and his Bahraini counterpart landed in Israel on Wednesday to mark a new, U.S.-brokered normalization deal just hours after Israeli forces carried out retaliatory airstrikes on Iranian targets in Syria.

Headline: France surpasses two million cases, and other news from around the world.
Lead Paragraph: Even as France became the first country in Europe to pass two million detected cases of coronavirus infection this week, authorities expressed optimism that weeks of restrictions on movement and social interactions were starting to slow the spread of the virus.

Headline: Michigan Republicans Backtrack After Refusing to Certify Election Results
Lead Paragraph: DETROIT — Republican members of a key Michigan elections board refused on Tuesday to certify Detroit’s election results in a nakedly partisan effort to hold up Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory over President Trump — only to reverse themselves after an outcry from the city’s voters and state officials.

Headline: Local officials rebut 3 dead-voter claims by the Trump campaign.
Lead Paragraph: Last week, the Trump campaign published a series of posts on Facebook and Twitter identifying dead Americans whose names, the campaign alleged, were used to cast votes in this month’s election. The seven people were from Georgia and Pennsylvania, two battleground states that were crucial to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.

Headline: Somalia Worries That a U.S. Withdrawal Will Be Disastrous
Lead Paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The American-trained Somali commando force Danab is usually deployed to counter the Qaeda-linked group Al Shabab: liberating areas it controls, ending its attacks on government offices and beachside restaurants, and targeting senior Shabab operatives.

Headline: Apple will pay $113 million to settle states’ investigation into battery throttling.
Lead Paragraph: Apple agreed on Wednesday to pay $113 million to settle an investigation by more than 30 states into its past practice of secretly slowing down older iPhones to preserve their battery life.

Headline: G.O.P. officials refused to certify Michigan ballots over issues that are fairly common.
Lead Paragraph: For a few hours on Tuesday, it looked as though two Republican officials in Wayne County, Mich., might reject the will of hundreds of thousands of voters.

Headline: A mini-outbreak on Capitol Hill threatens to disrupt the business of Congress.
Lead Paragraph: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, 87, on Tuesday became the latest lawmaker to be affected by the virus, announcing that he had tested positive. His absence helped to temporarily derail the confirmation of President Trump’s nominee for the Federal Reserve Board and shattered Mr. Grassley’s pride and joy, the longest consecutive voting streak in Senate history.

Headline: A new outbreak in Australia prompts a six-day lockdown in one state.
Lead Paragraph: The state of South Australia will go into lockdown for six days in an effort to contain a growing coronavirus outbreak. The cluster, which has been traced to a traveler quarantining in a hotel, has included 22 cases since Saturday.

Headline: In Georgia, a Republican Feud With Trump at the Center
Lead Paragraph: ATLANTA — There is no worse time for Georgia Republicans to be engulfed in a civil war. Their presidential candidate just narrowly lost the state, which has long been a conservative safe space, while two competitive runoff races are looming in January that could determine control of the U.S. Senate — and the direction of the country for the first part of this decade.

Headline: U.S. Troops Are Packing Up, Ready or Not
Lead Paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Had it not been for dozens of U.S. airstrikes in recent weeks, the southern hub city Kandahar would be under siege, after Taliban fighters threatened to overrun several surrounding districts, security officials say.

Headline: F.D.A. authorizes the first at-home coronavirus test.
Lead Paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday gave an emergency green light to the first rapid coronavirus test that can run from start to finish at home, paving a potential path for more widespread testing outside of health care settings.

Headline: ‘Now, We Fight Face to Face’: Thailand’s Protests Shatter Taboos
Lead Paragraph: BANGKOK — In unison, antigovernment protesters on Wednesday called the King of Thailand a giant monitor lizard, one of the worst things that can be said of anyone in Thai, and spray-painted bus stops and pavement in the capital’s central business district with graffiti describing his sexual activity.

Headline: No, the Army didn’t seize a German server showing a Trump landslide.
Lead Paragraph: Allies of President Trump are spreading another baseless rumor about computer-based vote manipulation, days after they gained attention for falsely claiming that a widely used piece of election administration software had been used to delete votes for the president.

Headline: Senators take aim at Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey.
Lead Paragraph: Senators took the chief executives of Facebook and Twitter to task on Tuesday for how the services handled misinformation around the election, showing bipartisan support for changing a law that protects the companies from lawsuits.

Headline: Seeking Restart With Biden, Palestinians Eye End to Prisoner Payments
Lead Paragraph: JERUSALEM — In a bold move to refurbish their sullied image in Washington, the Palestinians are laying the groundwork for an overhaul to one of their most cherished but controversial practices, officials say: compensating those who serve time in Israeli prisons, including for violent attacks.

Headline: They Championed Venezuela’s Revolution. They Are Now Its Latest Victims.
Lead Paragraph: GÜIRIA, Venezuela — The host of a popular radio show, “The People’s Combat,” had always diligently praised Venezuela’s governing Socialist Party, even as millions sank into penury under its rule. But when acute gasoline shortages paralyzed his remote fishing town this summer, he strayed from the party line.

Headline: Air Travel Was Gaining Momentum. Now What?
Lead Paragraph: Confidence about the course of the coronavirus pandemic has helped put passengers back on planes in recent months, and Thanksgiving week is shaping up to be one of the busiest periods for U.S. air travel since it came to a near-standstill in the spring. News that effective vaccines may be close at hand lifted airline stocks.

Headline: Toronto’s Biggest Mass Killing Case Goes to Trial on Video
Lead Paragraph: TORONTO — On a beautiful spring day, Cathy Riddell was making her way to the public library when she was slammed by a van plowing down the sidewalk.

Headline: At The Ringer, Staff Writers Say They Are Second-String
Lead Paragraph: The head coach of the Golden State Warriors. A former ace of the New York Yankees. A onetime star of “The Bachelorette.”

Headline: Boeing’s 737 Max is approved to fly again, but there’s more to be done before airlines can start using it.
Lead Paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration lifted its ban on Boeing’s 737 Max on Wednesday, allowing the plane to return to the skies after being grounded for more than 20 months following crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia that killed 346 people.

Headline: A Timeline of the Certification Process That Trump Is Trying to Disrupt
Lead Paragraph: As President Trump and his Republican allies continue trying to undermine the election, the certification of the vote totals in each state is the next major step in formalizing President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.

Headline: States that imposed few restrictions now have the worst outbreaks.
Lead Paragraph: Coronavirus cases are rising in almost every U.S. state. But the surge is worst now in places where leaders neglected to keep up forceful virus containment efforts or failed to implement basic measures like mask mandates in the first place, according to a New York Times analysis of data from the University of Oxford.

Headline: Dublin Zoo Pleaded for Pandemic Help. Supporters Gave $1.2 Million in Hours.
Lead Paragraph: Amid a second pandemic lockdown in Ireland, many businesses are struggling to stay afloat, with funds dwindling and no end of the coronavirus in sight.

Headline: As the U.S. nears the 200,000 daily case mark, Americans are urged to avoid Thanksgiving travel.
Lead Paragraph: The United States has set yet another record: 183,000 new daily cases.

Headline: Landslide in Ecuador Kills 5 at Illegal Mine
Lead Paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — A landslide killed at last five people on Wednesday and sent emergency workers on a frantic rescue mission in a remote part of northern Ecuador known for illegal gold mining.

Headline: The Coronavirus Is Airborne Indoors. Why Are We Still Scrubbing Surfaces?
Lead Paragraph: HONG KONG — At Hong Kong’s deserted airport, cleaning crews constantly spray baggage trolleys, elevator buttons and check-in counters with antimicrobial solutions. In New York City, workers continually disinfect surfaces on buses and subways. In London, many pubs spent lots of money on intensive surface cleaning to reopen after lockdown — before closing again in November.

Headline: Johnson, Seen as a Trump Ally, Signals Alignment With Biden
Lead Paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson rolled out ambitious, back-to-back initiatives on military spending and climate change this week, which have little in common except that both are likely to please a very important new person in Mr. Johnson’s life: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.

Headline: UNICEF warns of a ‘lost generation’ and finds school closures are ineffective.
Lead Paragraph: One of the small mercies of the coronavirus is that the risk of serious illness in children has so far been relatively small. But that does not mean that the toll has not been devastating.

Headline: Blood Lust and Demigods: Behind an Australian Force’s Slaughter of Helpless Afghans
Lead Paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — They were the elite of the elite among Australian soldiers, with a record of daring raids in Afghanistan. But a twisted and extreme warrior culture was being instilled, driving the commandos to glorify atrocity as they waged a methodical campaign to kill helpless Afghans and cover it up.

Headline: How Sidney Powell inaccurately cited Venezuela’s elections as evidence of U.S. fraud.
Lead Paragraph: Sidney Powell, a lawyer on President Trump’s election legal team who represented the former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, has been a major source and promoter of viral conspiracy theories about vote switching.

Headline: Roblox, edging toward I.P.O., reveals surging revenue and losses.
Lead Paragraph: Roblox, a gaming site and app that has been a huge hit with tweens, revealed in an offering prospectus on Thursday that its number of users and revenue surged during the coronavirus pandemic, but that its losses deepened.

Headline: Virus Cases Rise, but Hazard Pay for Retail Workers Doesn’t
Lead Paragraph: With coronavirus cases rising across the country, retailers are preparing for another rush from shoppers worried about new lockdowns and pandemic shortages.

Headline: G.M. Accelerates Its Ambitions for Electric Vehicles
Lead Paragraph: For the last few years, Tesla has not only dominated the market for electric cars but also captivated the imaginations of investors, a phenomenon that has lifted its market value to stratospheric heights even though it only just started turning consistent profits.

Headline: No, judges don’t overturn elections because of isolated irregularities.
Lead Paragraph: President Trump’s approach to challenging the election has been scattershot and contradictory, as his campaign demands that courts stop ballots from being counted in certain places while insisting that a more thorough review is necessary in other places.

Headline: Many Employers Avoid Coronavirus Tests Over Cost, Not Availability
Lead Paragraph: A surge of Covid-19 cases this fall has brought reports of new challenges in getting coronavirus tests. But for employers, testing availability and turnaround times do not appear to be the main obstacles.

Headline: Egypt Arrests Human Rights Leader, Continuing Crackdown on Dissent
Lead Paragraph: CAIRO — The executive director of one of Egypt’s leading human rights organizations was arrested Thursday night, the group said, joining two staff members detained earlier this week and thousands of opposition figures, protesters and activists already in prison.

Headline: With Senate Control Hanging in Balance, ‘Crazytown’ Cash Floods Georgia
Lead Paragraph: The two Georgia runoff elections that will determine control of the Senate, and much of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s ability to enact a Democratic agenda, are already drawing enormous sums of cash, with more than $125 million pouring into the state in only two weeks.

Headline: BuzzFeed to Acquire HuffPost From Verizon Media
Lead Paragraph: After falling prey to some of the same business difficulties that have plagued newspapers and magazines, the digital-media giants BuzzFeed and HuffPost have decided to join forces, the companies announced on Thursday.

Headline: Millionaire Preacher Skips Bail in South Africa, Fueling International Dispute
Lead Paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Shepherd Bushiri, a multimillionaire pastor with a network of churches across Africa, has claimed he can walk on air and harness the power of God to cure people of H.I.V.

Headline: An Arms Race in Car Stereos
Lead Paragraph: Throughout the lengthy era B.B. — Before Bose — the choices for a music-loving car buyer ranged from primitive to over the top.

Headline: Biden Turns Up the Heat on the G.S.A.
Lead Paragraph: The Trump administration presses for a recount in Wisconsin, while Nancy Pelosi braces for a thinner majority. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

Headline: A Chinese County Aims to Curb Dog Walking by Threatening to Kill the Dog
Lead Paragraph: HONG KONG — In a southwestern corner of China, walking a dog can potentially get the animal killed by the authorities.

Headline: The culling of minks in Denmark prompts a political crisis.
Lead Paragraph: The slaughter of minks in Denmark to prevent the spread of a potentially dangerous new strain of the coronavirus has prompted a political crisis in the country, with the minister of agriculture forced to step down and the government in danger of collapse.

Headline: What We Learned From the DealBook Online Summit
Lead Paragraph: Thanks to all who joined us at this week’s DealBook Online Summit. If you missed any of the sessions, you can watch them here. Our next event, the DealBook D.C. Online Strategy Forum, will be held on Dec. 2-3. More details to come.

Headline: President-elect Biden says he has chosen a Treasury secretary.
Lead Paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Thursday that he had chosen his nominee for Treasury secretary and that he would announce the pick in the near future.

Headline: The surge in coronavirus cases is helping speed up the development of vaccines.
Lead Paragraph: There is a slender silver lining to the out-of-control pandemic: It is hastening the testing of vaccines that could eventually end it.

Headline: Mnuchin to End Key Fed Emergency Programs, Limiting Biden
Lead Paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said he does not plan to extend several key emergency lending programs beyond the end of the year and asked the Federal Reserve to return the money supporting them, a decision that could hinder President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s ability to use the central bank’s vast powers to cushion the economic fallout from the virus.

Headline: Unemployment Claims Rise as Economic Worries Grow
Lead Paragraph: The job market is showing signs of weakening again, as more Americans file for unemployment benefits amid a sharp rise in coronavirus cases and new restrictions on business aimed at curbing the outbreak.

Headline: Pompeo Visits West Bank Settlement and Offers Parting Gifts to Israeli Right
Lead Paragraph: JERUSALEM — The high point of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s valedictory trip to Israel could easily have been the long, grateful recitation by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Thursday of the gifts that the Trump administration has bestowed upon his right-wing government.

Headline: Giuliani makes accusations of fraud that the Trump team has failed to support in court.
Lead Paragraph: At a rambling news conference on Thursday, Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, mixed misleading statements, wild conspiracy theories and outright fabrications as he attempted to suggest that Mr. Trump still had a viable pathway to winning the election.

Headline: Why Covid Caused Such Suffering in Italy’s Wealthiest Region
Lead Paragraph: LONDON — Dr. Chiara Lepora had never imagined being deployed in her home country of Italy. As a physician for the international relief agency Doctors Without Borders, she was accustomed to caring for people in countries like Yemen and South Sudan, amid extreme poverty and war.

Headline: Threats and Tensions Rise as Trump and Allies Attack Elections Process
Lead Paragraph: President Trump’s false accusations that voter fraud denied him re-election are causing escalating confrontations in swing states across the country, leading to threats of violence against officials in both parties and subverting even the most routine steps in the electoral process.

Headline: Dutch Police Urge Public to Stop ‘Pedo-Hunting’ After Vigilante Violence
Lead Paragraph: When a group of teenagers arranged a meeting with a 73-year-old former teacher, their intention was clear: to lure and expose someone they believed to be a pedophile.

Headline: The Pacific island nation of Samoa records its first case of the virus.
Lead Paragraph: A sailor who returned to Samoa on a repatriation flight from New Zealand has tested positive for the coronavirus, the first known case in Samoa, Prime Minister Tuilaepa Sailele Malielegaoi announced on Thursday.

Headline: Japan, facing a third wave, goes on ‘maximum alert’ as new infections reach record highs.
Lead Paragraph: Japan has managed to keep coronavirus numbers low, but its strategy for success is being tested as cases reach record highs across the country.

Headline: An Angel on the Shoulder of Your Teenage Driver (or at Least a Snitch)
Lead Paragraph: Technological advances have made cars safer in many ways. There are systems that brake if a collision is imminent; warn the driver and take control if the car leaves the lane, and issue alerts when pedestrians are about to step into the road. To those, add systems that will warn parents if their teenager is misbehaving behind the wheel.

Headline: ‘Wonder Woman 1984’ will open in theaters and on HBO Max on Christmas.
Lead Paragraph: “Wonder Woman 1984,” the last potential blockbuster remaining on the 2020 movie calendar, will open both in theaters and on WarnerMedia’s new streaming service, HBO Max, on Dec. 25, the company announced Wednesday.

Headline: Remote-only learning returns to New York City schools.
Lead Paragraph: Parents across New York City scrambled on Thursday morning to find child care and set up their children for full-time remote instruction less than a day after learning that public schools would shut because of rising coronavirus cases.

Headline: A Washington Tragedy
Lead Paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

Headline: Giuliani in Public: ‘It’s a Fraud.’ Giuliani in Court: ‘This Is Not a Fraud Case.’
Lead Paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

Headline: Jordan, once a model of virus control, is now a hot spot.
Lead Paragraph: Jordan, which was commended worldwide for its early efforts to counter the pandemic, has now become one of the hardest-hit countries in the region, along with Lebanon and Iran.

Headline: Will Lara Trump Be the Next Trump on a Ballot?
Lead Paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lara Trump, the president’s daughter-in-law who emerged during the 2020 presidential campaign as a defender of President Trump’s basest political instincts, is now eyeing a political future of her own in her home state of North Carolina.

Headline: Deadly Protests Erupt in Uganda After Arrest of 2 Opposition Figures
Lead Paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The national police in Uganda said Thursday that at least 16 people had been killed and hundreds arrested in protests that erupted across the country after two presidential candidates were arrested while campaigning ahead of a highly anticipated January election.

Headline: No, Trump’s sister did not publicly back him. He was duped by a fake account.
Lead Paragraph: On Friday morning, President Trump shared a seemingly innocuous article on Twitter. The piece said that his sister, Elizabeth Trump Grau, had publicly voiced her support for her brother amid his baseless claims that he won the 2020 election.

Headline: Fighting the virus, the University of Michigan battens down the hatches.
Lead Paragraph: The University of Michigan’s flagship campus in Ann Arbor opened the fall semester with great expectations. Thousands of students were welcomed back to the dorms in August.

Headline: Senator Rick Scott of Florida is the latest member of Congress to test positive.
Lead Paragraph: Senator Rick Scott, Republican of Florida, said Friday he had tested positive for the coronavirus, the latest prominent lawmaker to contract the rapidly spreading virus that has infected at least eight members of Congress over the past week.

Headline: Mnuchin Cites Principles in Clawing Back Fed Money. Democrats See Politics.
Lead Paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin broke sharply with the Federal Reserve this week, choosing to end a variety of programs aimed at helping markets, businesses and municipalities weather the pandemic and asking the central bank to return the funds earmarked to support those efforts.

Headline: After Trump’s Embrace, Saudis Brace for a Chillier Tone From Biden
Lead Paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For the last four years, President Trump’s close relationship with Saudi Arabia meant that there was seemingly nothing its de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, could do to earn a rebuke from the White House.

Headline: A senior Defense Department official is infected with the virus, and others were exposed.
